sn35.243:1.2: The completion of a town hall was celebrated by a talk for the Sakyans at MN 53:2.1 and the Mallas at DN 33:1.2.1. Such halls were community meeting places that played a central role in civic society and communal decision-making in democratic republics such as the Mallas and the Sakyans. The Buddha’s participation is a sign of his support for their civic and democratic process; he is not said to attend any comparable civic events for kings.
sn35.243:2.8: The Buddha refers to the Sakyans as “Gotamas” after the lineage of the family priest (purohita). Thus “Gotama” is not a personal name of the Buddha. In a similar context at DN 33:1.4.5, the Buddha refers to the Mallas after their priestly lineage, Vāseṭṭha.
sn35.243:3.4: The Buddha’s bad back is mentioned several times in similar contexts, suggesting that such events took place in his old age. It serves as a reminder that freedom from attachment to the body does not mean one must forcefully endure pain.
sn35.243:3.12: “Festering” is avassuta, literally “that which has been flowed down into”.
